comments.message: I think these device specific definitions belong in the device specific module.  So in this case, dhub_light.py.
This seems like a good approach, but these fixtures don't relate to the DataHub.  Maybe there should be a sensorhub_common.py?
Yes, the library should be sensorhub_common.py
Just like the IMU.  Just needs one little change and I think it's good.
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 28d2c1ca3cbf8853e9275806ed2e6574e0b93d8b

comments.message: Patch 2 is based on the update in confluence page and David's comments. Please help to review it.
What do you think about putting these into testlib/sensorhub_common.py?
I think this should just say: "Check MCU CLI is up"

dhub push /app/sensor/humidity_and_temperature/trigger

The trigger takes no value, so the "1" at the end of the command is incorrect.
I think that these paths should instead be in sensorhub_tests/testlib/dhub_temperature_and_humidity.py since they are specific to that sensor.
Patchset 3 is based on David's comments. Please help to review again
Patchset 3 was rebased for resolving merge conflict

comments.message:
I think this test (and all others) would be easier to read if aliases were introduced for the ports.  Something like:

    bx3105_port = target.slink3
    hl78mcu_port = target.slink2
    hl78map_port = target.slink1 # not sure if this is correct
    ...
    bx3105_port.send("\r\n")
    bx3105_port.expect("sh-bx> ")
Apelete: What do you expect this test to prove?  The DataHub will always report back what you push into it, but it doesn't indicate that this was correctly applied to the hardware.

M.ST.3 is the test that actually verifies that the set threshold has been applied by watching for the value to be returned when threshold is exceeded.
Test requirements were also updated to provide more effective test coverage overall.
Does this testing requirement make sense?  The current set of DataHub resources for this sensor do not express what the maximum and minimum frequencies are.
Requirements shall be updated to remove this test maximum and minimum frequencies cannot be queried through DataHub.
I don't think that this type of test has value.  I think we actually need to enable periodic sampling and then measure the time between samples to ensure that it's as expected.

I mentioned this in another review, but I think any common functions should be put on a common module and imported so that we're not duplicating effort trying to maintain multiple versions of the same test code.

I realize this is probably a testing requirements issue, but I don't think there's value in pushing enable true and then verifying that it shows true.

Apelete: I think we need to update the testing requirements a bit.
Patch 4 is based on update in confluence page and David's comments. Please help to review again.
Patchset 5 is based on David's comment. Please help to review again
Please use patch set 6 for the review. Thanks
Patchset 6 was rebased for resolving merge conflict
These git conflict markers are still present throughout the file, please resolve conflict and remove appropriately.

commits.commitMessage:
[SH-119] Add scripts for Accelerometer sensor

Resolves: SH-119
Change-Id: I7e07473347e18511568f7dd533e978b72960a360
commits.subject: [SH-119] Add scripts for Accelerometer sensor

comments.message: I think you could just set enable to false to enter the lowest power state
This will definitely overload the system and fail.  I'm not sure what the maximum speed is that will work reliably, but it's way lower than this.

Apelete Seketeli,
What is the best output data rate (High Performance mode)?
Most (all?) of these functions are identical to test_HL78_MCU_Accelerometers_M_SA_1.py.  Can we create a file for dhub helper functions so that these don't have to be copy/pasted into every test?

How is this test expected to work?  When the device is in "motion" mode, it will update the motion_state to either be "stationary" or "moving" depending on whether the device is in motion.  For this test to pass, the device will have to physically move.  Are these tests expected to be able to run without human intervention?
With 'moving' state: this case needs to the support of tester with moving the sensor to verify 'moving' state

I think the purpose of this requirement is to ensure that the enable/disable functionality is working correctly.  What I would suggest:

1. Set enable to false
2. Set mode to periodic
3. sleep 100 ms
4. Get the timestamp of the value resource and record it
5. Larger sleep
6. Get the timestamp of the value resource and ensure that it's still the same as above. This proves that no samples were received during this time that the device was disabled.
7. Set the ODRs and set enable to true
8. sleep 5s
9. Get the timestamp of the value resource and compare it to the value recorded earlier.  The new timestamp should be later.
10. Repeat steps 1 through 6 above to ensure that enable=false works after enable was true

Updated requirement M.SA.3 to reflect this and provide more effective testing.
Kiet, please update the test script accordingly.
Does sensor_fixture above already handle setting enable to false when the test starts?
sensor_fixture to back to Idle mode after executing the test case (set 'enable' to false)
One minor change and I think this is done.
SensorHub utitlites.  Not all of these functions are related to dhub

With regard to sensorhub_tests/testlib/sensorhub_common.py, this change should be the first to be merged and the following test scripts rebased accordingly ; this is an arbitrary choice, let me know if another of the sensors' test scripts should be prioritized instead.
OK, this test script can be merged in the first and the following test scripts will rebase accordingly.
